docs.lead_paragraph: FOREIGN A3-9 Iraqi Talk Radio Station Acts as Frustration Outlet Iraq has its first talk radio station, Radio Dijla, which opened in April and has been putting Iraqis' opinions on the air, mainlining democracy from a villa in central Baghdad for 19 hours a day. About 15 private radio stations have sprung up since the American occupation began, but Dijla, Arabic for Tigris, is the first to serve only talk. A1 Two French journalists held hostage in Iraq urged France to give in to their captors' demand and revoke a law banning Muslim head scarves in schools, Al Jazeera reported. Otherwise, the hostages said, they might be killed. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: They exude serene confidence about President Bush's re-election prospects. They talk of his likability and say the Iraq war and the economy should help him, not hurt him. And they plain don't like Senator John Kerry -- or his wife. They are the president's front-line warriors in the battleground states, the Republican delegates and alternates from those too-close-to-call states that will decide the next election. And as the Republican National Convention got under way in New York yesterday, they spoke with great confidence about how they see the race shaping up.

headline.main: Swing-State Delegates Confident in Bush and Don't Much Like Kerry
headline.kicker: THE REPUBLICANS: THE CONVENTION IN NEW YORK -- THE CONVENTIONEERS

docs.abstract: Republican delegates from swing states are confident in ability to bring their states into Pres Bush's column; express deep distrust and dislike for Sen John Kerry, calling him unsuitable for presidency; many delegates express dislike also for Kerry's wife Teresa Heinz Kerry; some comments noted; photos (M)

byline.original: By MICHAEL COOPER; Thomas Crampton, Mark Glassman and Marc Santora contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans seem to suffer a disconnect between what logic dictates is good for their health and what they do. They exercise, but they also sunbathe. They eat large salads instead of dinner, but snack on high-calorie, high-cholesterol junk foods. This habit extends down to the toes, or at least the toes of many women. Just ask the podiatrists and foot and ankle surgeons who do a brisk business in repairing feet wounded by the fashion industry's love affair with high-heeled shoes.

headline.main: In the Relentless Pursuit of Fashion, the Feet Pay the Price

docs.abstract: American women continue wearing high-heeled shoes despite variety of problems they can cause; Dr Tzvi Bar-David, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center podiatrist, holds that high heels, particularly ones with narrow toes, can cause shortening of Achilles' tendon, ankle sprains, body aches and pain and damaged nerves; types of shoes and physical advantages and disadvantages of wearing them described; cosmetic foot surgery and spa treatments for feet, which are growing in popularity, discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Americans seem to suffer a disconnect between what logic dictates is good for their health and what they do. They exercise, but they also sunbathe. They eat large salads instead of dinner, but snack on high-calorie, high-cholesterol junk foods.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: GETTING around during the Republican National Convention is unlikely to be easy, but there are options. These should not include driving yourself -- parking spots will be in more demand than undecided voters. Here are other modes of transportation, with the approximate weekday cost and travel time to Madison Square Garden (Seventh Avenue at 32nd Street) from that upper-crust landmark, the Plaza Hotel (Fifth Avenue at 59th Street). Yellow Cab COST: $9 plus $2 tip. TIME: 20 minutes. TRAVEL NOTES: One of the easiest ways to make it to the convention, cabs will be out in force, making their way through the grinding traffic. If your driver appears to be talking to himself or herself, don't worry -- there is probably a hands-free cellphone involved. Probably.

headline.main: Follow That Horse-Drawn Carriage, and Step on It

docs.lead_paragraph: The ebb tide of the 2001 recession and its aftermath didn't strand all boats equally, the government reported Thursday. Figures for 2003 released by the United States Census Bureau indicated that income inequality has grown since 2002. In 2003, the bureau reported, the number of people considered poor and those without health insurance grew for the third straight year, and families near the bottom and middle were suffering the most.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Almost 16 percent of Americans are without health care. Corporations are cutting health care benefits, health care providers cherry-pick whom they insure, and Americans can pay twice as much for drugs in the United States than people pay in Canada.

headline.main: Who Should Pay Our Medical Bills?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman (''America's Failing Health,'' column, Aug. 27) argues convincingly for a single-payer health care system, but then cites health economists who claim such a goal is politically unrealistic. With all due respect to those, like me, in that profession, economists don't always have the best political antennas. Especially where health care is concerned, many economists still believe that markets can save the day, despite the lesson from international comparisons that the best way to provide health care is to take it out of the market.

headline.main: Who Should Pay Our Medical Bills?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman says that the prohibitive cost to American employers of providing health insurance is eating away at jobs. But the insurers are not operating in a vacuum here. Look at doctors' fees. As a Canadian who has lived in the United States for 14 years, I am awed by the size of claims some American doctors make.

docs.lead_paragraph: NOW that the work force is growing again, President Bush and Senator John Kerry have been arguing about the quality of the newly created jobs -- whether a majority are toward the higher or lower end of the wage scale. That is the wrong debate. The real issue is not how well the new jobs pay, but whether the incomes of workers in general are rising or falling. On the second score, there is not much to debate. The incomes of most workers, adjusted for inflation, are sinking. The evidence for this assertion is piling up. The Census Bureau weighed in last week with the latest update on family and household incomes. Both declined through the first three years of the Bush administration. From the Bureau of Labor Statistics comes a similar story for individual workers. Whether the measure is median weekly pay or average weekly pay, the increases have been too small since last summer to keep up with a measly climb of 1 percentage point in the inflation rate.

headline.main: It's Not New Jobs. It's All The Jobs.

docs.abstract: Economic View column says Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry are arguing about quality of newly created jobs, now that work force is growing again; says real issue is not how well new jobs pay, but whether incomes of workers in general are rising or falling; says answer is that incomes of most workers, adjusted for inflation, are sinking; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE good news is we are living longer than ever before. The bad news is it's going to cost us. As global fertility rates grow more slowly and increasing prosperity enhances life expectancy, a complicated side effect has emerged: big chunks of the world are starting to look like geriatric wards. It is uncertain how the world will pay for them.

headline.main: The World -- Economic Strains; Old, in the Way And Hard at Work

docs.abstract: As global fertility rates grow more slowly and increasing prosperity enhances life expectancy, complicated side effect has emerged; big chunks of world are starting to look like geriatric wards; it is uncertain how world will pay for them; aging will put stress on government finances, drawing money from budgets to pay for pensions and health care; photos; graph (M)
